title: Is it acceptable to start a novel with 'She was beautiful while she lasted', with reference to a historic city? - Quora

response.answer_text: You can, but it’s not a strong start. The sentence doesn’t make it obvious that “she” is a place rather than a person. It’s acceptable to start a novel any way you like. Your book, your rules. But you want the start to be evocative and engage your reader. “She was beautiful while she lasted” doesn’t do that. It’s not a bad idea, it just needs to be made more evocative. Perhaps something like “She was beautiful once, this city by the sea, though her beauty had long since faded, her once magnificent tree-lined streets now overgrown and shabby, her stately Victorian mansions decaying into ruin.”

In a writing class, the professor was talking about how to start a story, and was critiquing a student’s work, and abruptly said, “Just cut the first paragraph. Now look how it starts: ‘Of course he was late.’ That’s a great way to start. Who is he? Why was he late? What was he late for? Why of course? In five words you put four questions into the reader’s mind.” I think you have to give the reader information fast enough that they don’t feel lost at sea and give up, but you want to put questions in their mind, make them curious, make them care. It’s a balancing act. But if you are going to be mysterious, please please remember a rule of writing so basic that I’ve never seen it written down anywhere, yet Hollywood has managed to forget it: If you are writing a mystery, You must know Who Dunnit! (I’ll never forgive the writers of LOST.)
